did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Collection of Thomas A. Stevens, circa 1770-1964
did.abstract: The Thomas A. Stevens collection contains a variety of types of materials collected by Stevens that reflect his wide-ranging interests in maritime and Connecticut history. The collection is comprised of, but not limited to, correspondence, logbooks, journals, accounts, bills of lading, drawings, tickets, manifests, cargo lists, custom lists and forms, registers and enrollments.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Tom Stevens (1901-1982) lived in Deep River, Connecticut. He graduated from Northeastern University and worked as an electrical engineer at the Boston Edison Company until 1942. He served in World War II as a Commander in the Navy and was active in both the Atlantic and Pacific Theatres of Operations. After the war he served as the Managing Director of the Marine Historical Association at Mystic (later known as Mystic Seaport) until 1949. He returned to Deep River to form the Deep River Hardware Corporation which he ran until 1970. He was Town Clerk of Deep River from 1949 to 1951 and Chairman of the Town’s Board of Finance for the following six years. He was also a Director of the Deep River Savings Bank and a past President of Northeastern University Alumni Association. In 1955 he initiated legislation which established the Connecticut Historical Commission and he was the first member of the Commission appointed by Governor Ribbicoff and served on this Commission for the next twelve years. He assisted in the formation of many historical societies and served as the vice-president of the Connecticut League of Historical Societies (now CLHO).

Stevens descended from a long line of ship captains which established a lifelong interest in maritime history, particularly shipbuilding, ship captains, and history of the Connecticut River. He collected material relating to the history of the lower River Valley and established a substantial library and archives in support of his scholarly interests. He was a frequent writer of historical topics which appeared in local newspapers and he lectured frequently throughout Connecticut. He was a founder of the Connecticut River Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Thomas A. Stevens collection is comprised of originals and photocopies housed in 33 document boxes that document maritime and Connecticut history from the late eighteenth through much of the twentieth century. Stevens organized the collection into seven series; material includes correspondence, logbooks, journals, accounts, bills of lading, drawings, tickets, manifests, cargo lists, custom lists and forms, registers and enrollments and other items.

Series I – Ships Records: logs, journals and accounts, circa 1789-1964 - Records of steam and sail vessels built along or operated along the lower Connecticut River Valley or coastal Connecticut. Most are merchant vessels that served a variety of purposes including passenger and cargo.

Series II -Maritime Individuals, circa 1785-1936 - Papers, correspondence and business records of individuals in the lower Connecticut River Valley who were engaged in maritime commerce of one kind or another including shipbuilding, provisioning, rope-making, carpentry. Also included are papers of ship captains and investors in maritime trade.
Series III – West Indies documents, 1777-1846 - Middletown customs records.
Series IV – Business Records, circa 1770-1931 - Records of local businesses, including merchants’ daybooks, account books, railroad receipts, Union House Company minutes of stockholders meetings.
Series V – Town Records, circa 1876 - Borough of Essex bylaws, list of officers, other miscellaneous records for Essex, Deep River, Saybrook.
Series VI – Societies, 1847-1863 - Three bound volumes of various groups, including Boston Marine Society, Sons of Temperance and the Theta Epsilon Society.
Series VII – Antarctic Explorations 1820-1977 - Photocopies of logs and log plots, miscellaneous papers, papers authored by Thomas A. Stevens, Antarctic Bulletin (published material).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged in seven series, and housed in numbered folders and boxes, shelved in the archival vault in the museum Chandlery building.
